articles.title: Tyske Udtryk til F√∏lelsesm√¶ssig St√∏tte og Tr√∏st
articles.content:
# Tyske Udtryk til F√∏lelsesm√¶ssig St√∏tte og Tr√∏st

N√•r din tysktalende partner har brug for st√∏tte, er det vigtigt at kunne udtrykke omsorg p√• tysk. Selvom tysk ofte opfattes som et direkte sprog, er det lige s√• rigt p√• varme og tr√∏stende udtryk.

## Kulturelle Overvejelser

Tyskere v√¶rds√¶tter √¶rlighed og p√•lidelighed. St√∏tte gives ofte gennem praktiske handlinger kombineret med oprigtige ord. At vise, at du er der for din partner, betyder b√•de ord og handling.

## Grundl√¶ggende St√∏tteudtryk

### 1. Ich bin f√ºr dich da
**Udtale:** …™√ß b…™n fyÀê…ê d…™√ß daÀê (ikh bin fuer dikh da)

**Betydning:** Jeg er her for dig.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** N√•r din partner har brug for at vide, at du er tilg√¶ngelig.

### 2. Alles wird gut
**Udtale:** Ààal…ôs v…™ Åt …°uÀêt (A-les veert goot)

**Betydning:** Alt bliver godt.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** For at berolige om fremtiden.

### 3. Ich glaube an dich
**Udtale:** …™√ß Àà…°la äb…ô an d…™√ß (ikh GLOW-buh an dikh)

**Betydning:** Jeg tror p√• dig.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** N√•r din partner tvivler p√• sig selv.

### 4. Nimm dir so viel Zeit, wie du brauchst
**Udtale:** n…™m diÀê…ê zoÀê fiÀêl tÕ°sa…™t viÀê duÀê b Åa äxst (nim deer zoh feel tsait vee doo browkhst)

**Betydning:** Tag s√• meget tid, som du har brug for.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** N√•r din partner har brug for tid.

### 5. Es tut mir sehr leid, was du durchmachst
**Udtale:** …õs tuÀêt miÀê…ê zeÀê…ê la…™t vas duÀê Ààd ä Å√ßmaxst (es toot meer zair lait vas doo DOORKH-makhst)

**Betydning:** Det g√∏r mig ondt, hvad du g√•r igennem.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** For at vise empati.

## Dybere Tr√∏st

### 6. Es ist okay zu weinen
**Udtale:** …õs …™st ÀàoÀêke…™ tÕ°suÀê Ààva…™n…ôn (es ist oh-KAY tsoo VAI-nen)

**Betydning:** Det er okay at gr√¶de.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** N√•r din partner holder f√∏lelserne tilbage.

### 7. Du musst das nicht alleine durchstehen
**Udtale:** duÀê m äst das n…™√ßt aÀàla…™n…ô Ààd ä Å√ß ÉteÀê…ôn (doo moost das nikht a-LAI-nuh DOORKH-shtay-en)

**Betydning:** Du beh√∏ver ikke st√• det her igennem alene.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** For at understrege jeres partnerskab.

### 8. Ich bin so stolz auf deine St√§rke
**Udtale:** …™√ß b…™n zoÀê  Ét…îltÕ°s a äf Ààda…™n…ô Àà Ét…õ Åk…ô (ikh bin zoh shtolts owf DAI-nuh SHTAIR-kuh)

**Betydning:** Jeg er s√• stolt af din styrke.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** For at anerkende din partners styrke.

### 9. Deine Gef√ºhle sind berechtigt
**Udtale:** Ààda…™n…ô …°…ôÀàfyÀêl…ô z…™nt b…ôÀà Å…õ√ßt…™√ßt (DAI-nuh guh-FUE-luh zint buh-REKH-tikht)

**Bedeutning:** Dine f√∏lelser er berettigede.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** N√•r din partner undskylder for sine f√∏lelser.

### 10. Was auch immer passiert, wir stehen das gemeinsam durch
**Udtale:** vas a äx Àà…™m…ê paÀàsiÀê…êt viÀê…ê Àà ÉteÀê…ôn das …°…ôÀàma…™nzaÀêm d ä Å√ß (vas owkh IM-er pa-ZEERT veer SHTAY-en das guh-MAIN-zam doorkh)

**Betydning:** Uanset hvad der sker, st√•r vi det igennem sammen.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** For at understrege jeres f√¶lles styrke.

## K√¶rlige Tr√∏steord

### 11. Mein Schatz, ich bin immer bei dir
**Udtale:** ma…™n  ÉatÕ°s …™√ß b…™n Àà…™m…ê ba…™ diÀê…ê (main shats ikh bin IM-er bai deer)

**Betydning:** Min skat, jeg er altid hos dig.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** En k√¶rlig bekr√¶ftelse af din st√∏tte.

### 12. Ich liebe dich, und daran wird sich nie etwas √§ndern
**Udtale:** …™√ß ÀàliÀêb…ô d…™√ß  änt daÀà Åan v…™ Åt z…™√ß niÀê Àà…õtvas Àà…õnd…ên (ikh LEE-buh dikh oont da-RAN veert zikh nee ET-vas EN-dern)

**Betydning:** Jeg elsker dig, og det vil aldrig √¶ndre sig.

**Hvorn√•r bruges det:** For at bekr√¶fte din urokkelige k√¶rlighed.

## Samtaleeksempel

**Partner:** Ich f√ºhle mich so √ºberfordert mit allem...
**Dig:** Es tut mir sehr leid, was du durchmachst. Ich bin f√ºr dich da.
**Partner:** Ich wei√ü nicht, ob ich das schaffe.
**Dig:** Ich glaube an dich. Und du musst das nicht alleine durchstehen ‚Äì wir stehen das gemeinsam durch.

## Afsluttende R√•d

Tyskere v√¶rds√¶tter p√•lidelighed og handlinger. Vis din st√∏tte gennem b√•de ord og handlinger ‚Äì lav en kop te, tag dig af praktiske ting, eller bare v√¶r fysisk til stede. Kombinationen af varme ord og praktisk omsorg er den mest v√¶rdifulde st√∏tte.

articles.title: 50+ Duitse Liefkozingen om Harten te Veroveren
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Duitsers hebben een verrassend zachte kant als het om koosnamen gaat. Van de klassieke "Schatz" tot de meest creatieve diernamen - leer hier alle manieren om je geliefde te noemen in het Duits.

## De Klassiekers

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Schatz"
  translation="Schat"
  pronunciation="shahts"
  context="De meest gebruikte koosnaam in Duitsland - je hoort hem overal!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Schatz"
  translation="Schat"
  pronunciation="shahts"
  example="Schatz, hast du die Schl√ºssel gesehen?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Schatzi"
  translation="Schatje"
  pronunciation="SHAHT-sie"
  example="Schatzi, ich bin zu Hause!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Liebling"
  translation="Lieveling"
  pronunciation="LEEP-ling"
  example="Liebling, was m√∂chtest du essen?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Liebste/Liebster"
  translation="Liefste"
  pronunciation="LEEP-stuh/LEEP-ster"
  example="Mein Liebster, du machst mich so gl√ºcklich."
/>

<CultureTip title="Schatz Overal" flag="üá©üá™">
"Schatz" is zo populair dat je het zelfs tussen ouders en kinderen hoort. Tussen partners is het absoluut de nummer √©√©n koosnaam.
</CultureTip>

## Diernamen (Heel Populair!)

Duitsers houden ervan om hun partner naar schattige dieren te noemen:

<VocabCard
  word="Maus / Mausi"
  translation="Muisje"
  pronunciation="mows / MOW-zie"
  example="Mausi, kommst du ins Bett?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Hase / Hasi"
  translation="Konijntje"
  pronunciation="HAH-zuh / HAH-zie"
  example="Hasi, ich hab dich so lieb!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="B√§r / B√§rchen"
  translation="Beer / Beertje"
  pronunciation="behr / BEHR-shen"
  example="Mein gro√üer B√§r, umarme mich!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Schnecke"
  translation="Slakje"
  pronunciation="SHNEK-kuh"
  example="Na Schnecke, wie war dein Tag?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Spatz / Spatzi"
  translation="Musje"
  pronunciation="shpahts / SHPAHT-sie"
  example="Guten Morgen, mein Spatzi!"
/>

| Duits | Nederlands | Letterlijk |
|-------|------------|------------|
| Maus/Mausi | Muisje | Muis |
| Hase/Hasi | Konijntje | Haas |
| B√§rchen | Beertje | Kleine beer |
| Schnecke | Slakje | Slak |
| Spatz | Musje | Mus |
| Bienchen | Bijtje | Kleine bij |
| K√§tzchen | Poesje | Katje |

<CultureTip title="Kleine Versies" flag="üê≠">
Door "-chen" of "-i" toe te voegen maak je de koosnaam liever: Maus wordt Mausi of M√§uschen, Hase wordt Hasi of H√§schen. Dit zijn verkleiningvormen.
</CultureTip>

## Zoete Naampjes

<VocabCard
  word="S√º√üe / S√º√üer"
  translation="Zoetje / Lieve"
  pronunciation="ZUE-suh / ZUE-ser"
  example="Hey S√º√üe, ich hab eine √úberraschung f√ºr dich!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Engel"
  translation="Engel"
  pronunciation="ENG-el"
  example="Du bist mein Engel."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Engelchen"
  translation="Engeltje"
  pronunciation="ENG-el-shen"
  example="Schlaf gut, mein Engelchen."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Sonnenschein"
  translation="Zonnestraal"
  pronunciation="ZON-nen-shyn"
  example="Guten Morgen, mein Sonnenschein!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Sternchen"
  translation="Sterretje"
  pronunciation="SHTEHRN-shen"
  example="Du bist mein kleines Sternchen."
/>

## Creatieve en Speelse Namen

<VocabCard
  word="Schnucki"
  translation="Schatje (speels)"
  pronunciation="SHNOO-kie"
  example="Schnucki, lass uns ausgehen!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Schnuckiputzi"
  translation="Schatjepoepie"
  pronunciation="SHNOO-kie-POOT-sie"
  example="Mein Schnuckiputzi, du bist so s√º√ü!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Knuddelb√§r"
  translation="Knuffelbeer"
  pronunciation="KNOO-del-behr"
  example="Komm her, mein Knuddelb√§r!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Kuschelmaus"
  translation="Knuffelmuis"
  pronunciation="KOO-shel-mows"
  example="Meine kleine Kuschelmaus."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Schmuseb√§r"
  translation="Knuffelbeer"
  pronunciation="SHMOO-zuh-behr"
  example="Du bist mein Schmuseb√§r."
/>

<CultureTip title="Hoe Creatiever, Hoe Liever" flag="üíï">
Duitsers combineren graag woorden om unieke koosnamen te maken. "Kuschel" (knuffel) + "Maus" (muis) = Kuschelmaus. Wees creatief!
</CultureTip>

## Formele vs. Informele Sfeer

### Informeel (met je partner)
- Schatz, Schatzi
- Mausi, Hasi
- S√º√üe, Liebling

### Iets Formeler (in het openbaar)
- Liebling
- Schatz
- Liebe/Lieber

<VocabCard
  word="Meine Liebe / Mein Lieber"
  translation="Mijn lieve / Mijn beste"
  pronunciation="MY-nuh LEE-buh / myn LEE-ber"
  example="Meine Liebe, wir m√ºssen los."
/>

## Regionale Variaties

<VocabCard
  word="Schnegge"
  translation="Slakje (Zwabisch)"
  pronunciation="SHNEG-guh"
  example="Mei Schnegge! (Mijn slakje!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Schmusigel"
  translation="Knuffelegel (Beiers)"
  pronunciation="SHMOO-zie-gel"
  example="Du bist mein kleiner Schmusigel."
/>

| Regio | Koosnaam | Betekenis |
|-------|----------|-----------|
| Beieren | Spatzl | Musje |
| Oostenrijk | Schatzerl | Schatje |
| Zwitserland | Sch√§tzeli | Schatje |
| Zwaben | Schnegge | Slakje |

## Seizoensgebonden Koosnamen

<VocabCard
  word="Weihnachtsmaus"
  translation="Kerstmuisje"
  pronunciation="VY-nahkts-mows"
  example="Frohe Weihnachten, meine Weihnachtsmaus!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Osterhase"
  translation="Paashaas"
  pronunciation="OH-ster-hah-zuh"
  example="Mein s√º√üer Osterhase!"
/>

## Hoe Gebruik je Deze Koosnamen?

### Do's
- Gebruik ze in priv√© of met vertrouwde vrienden
- Varieer af en toe voor de lol
- Voeg "mein/meine" (mijn) toe voor extra liefde

### Don'ts
- Niet te veel gebruiken in formele situaties
- Vermijd ze bij de eerste dates
- Niet overdrijven met te veel verschillende namen

<VocabCard
  word="Mein Ein und Alles"
  translation="Mijn alles"
  pronunciation="myn ayn oont AL-les"
  example="Du bist mein Ein und Alles."
/>


## Snelle Referentiekaart

| Categorie | Koosnamen |
|-----------|-----------|
| Klassiek | Schatz, Liebling, S√º√üe |
| Dieren | Maus, Hase, B√§r, Spatz |
| Hemels | Engel, Sonnenschein, Stern |
| Speels | Schnucki, Knuddelb√§r |
| Samengesteld | Kuschelmaus, Schmuseb√§r |

## Tips voor Nederlanders

1. **Uitspraak 'sch'** - Klinkt als 'sj' in het Nederlands
2. **De 'z'** - Klinkt als 'ts' aan het begin van woorden
3. **Verkleining met '-chen'** - Maakt alles schattig!
4. **De Umlaut** - B√§r wordt B√§rchen (de '√§' klinkt als 'e')

<CultureTip title="Begin Klein" flag="üå±">
Begin met "Schatz" - het is universeel en altijd gepast. Naarmate je relatie groeit, kun je experimenteren met creatievere namen!
</CultureTip>

## Maak Je Eigen Koosnaam

Probeer deze formule:
**Knuffelwoord + Dier = Unieke Koosnaam**

Voorbeelden:
- Kuschel + Maus = Kuschelmaus
- Schmuse + B√§r = Schmuseb√§r
- Knuddel + Hase = Knuddelhase

<CTA
  text="Klaar om je Duitse partner te verrassen? Met Love Languages oefen je de uitspraak met AI-spraakchat - zonder oordeel. Je partner kan liefkozingen als 'woordcadeaus' naar je sturen, zodat je precies leert wat zij romantisch vinden. Samen leren, samen groeien."
  buttonText="Start Samen met Duits Leren"
/>

articles.title: Dutch Love Letter Writing: Sincere Phrases for Your Partner
articles.content:
A Dutch love letter (*liefdesbrief*) combines sincerity with genuine warmth. Dutch speakers value authentic expression, making your heartfelt letter a truly meaningful gift.

## The Dutch Approach to Love Letters

Dutch culture values directness and sincerity. A love letter in Dutch should be genuine and heartfelt rather than overly flowery‚Äîquality emotional expression over quantity of words.

## Opening Your Letter

### Salutations

**Mijn liefste**
*My dearest*

Tender and romantic.

**Mijn schat**
*My treasure*

The most common Dutch term of endearment.

**Lieve [name]**
*Dear [name]*

Warm and personal.

**Mijn alles**
*My everything*

They are everything to you.

## Expressing Your Feelings

### Opening Lines

**Ik schrijf je om te zeggen hoeveel ik van je hou**
*I'm writing to tell you how much I love you*

Direct and heartfelt opening.

**Woorden schieten tekort om uit te drukken wat ik voel**
*Words fall short to express what I feel*

Acknowledging the depth of emotion.

**Er is zoveel dat ik je wil zeggen**
*There is so much I want to tell you*

Creating anticipation.

### Declarations of Love

**Jij bent de belangrijkste persoon in mijn leven**
*You are the most important person in my life*

Clear declaration of significance.

**Elke dag hou ik meer van je**
*Every day I love you more*

Love that continues to grow.

**Bij jou heb ik het ware geluk gevonden**
*With you I have found true happiness*

They brought genuine happiness.

**Mijn hart is alleen van jou**
*My heart belongs only to you*

Exclusive devotion.

## Sincere Declarations

**Jij bent mijn zonnetje**
*You are my little sun*

They bring light and warmth.

**Door jou ben ik een beter mens**
*Through you I am a better person*

Their positive influence.

**Jij bent alles waar ik ooit van gedroomd heb**
*You are everything I ever dreamed of*

Dream come true.

## Remembering Special Moments

**Ik herinner me de dag dat we elkaar ontmoetten**
*I remember the day we met*

Nostalgic reflection.

**Elk moment met jou is bijzonder**
*Every moment with you is special*

Valuing time together.

**Onze herinneringen zijn mijn grootste schat**
*Our memories are my greatest treasure*

Memories treasured deeply.

## Looking to the Future

**Ik wil de rest van mijn leven met jou doorbrengen**
*I want to spend the rest of my life with you*

Commitment to shared future.

**Ik droom van een toekomst samen**
*I dream of a future together*

Shared hopes and dreams.

**Ik beloof voor altijd van je te houden**
*I promise to love you forever*

Eternal vow.

## Closing Your Letter

### Sign-Offs

**Met al mijn liefde**
*With all my love*

Classic and sincere.

**Voor altijd de jouwe**
*Forever yours*

Commitment in closing.

**Ik hou van je met heel mijn hart**
*I love you with all my heart*

Final declaration.

**Je [name] die van je houdt**
*Your [name] who loves you*

Personal sign-off.

## Tips for Writing

- **Be sincere**: Dutch speakers value genuine emotion
- **Be direct**: Say what you mean clearly
- **Be specific**: Mention real memories and qualities
- **Quality over quantity**: Better one heartfelt letter than many casual ones

Your Dutch love letter will be treasured for its sincerity and the genuine effort you put into expressing love in their language.

articles.title: Meeting Your Spanish Partner's Family
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Meeting your Spanish partner's family is an exciting and important milestone. Spanish families are warm, close-knit, and family gatherings are central to their culture. With the right phrases and cultural awareness, you'll win over your partner's parents and extended family.

## The Essential First Greeting

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Encantado/Encantada de conocerles"
  translation="Delighted to meet you (m/f speaker)"
  pronunciation="en-kan-TA-do/en-kan-TA-da de ko-no-THER-les"
  context="The perfect polite greeting when meeting your partner's parents. Use 'usted/ustedes' (formal you) until invited to use 't√∫'."
/>

## Greeting with Kisses

In Spain, greetings involve two kisses on the cheeks (right cheek first, then left). This applies to:
- Women greeting anyone
- Men greeting women
- Men often shake hands with other men initially

<VocabCard
  word="¬°Hola! Mucho gusto"
  translation="Hello! Nice to meet you"
  pronunciation="O-la! MOO-cho GOO-sto"
  example="¬°Hola! Mucho gusto. Soy [your name]."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Es un placer conocerles"
  translation="It's a pleasure to meet you"
  pronunciation="es oon pla-THER ko-no-THER-les"
  example="Es un verdadero placer conocerles por fin."
/>

<CultureTip title="The Two Kisses" flag="üá™üá∏">
Don't be surprised by the two-kiss greeting! It's standard in Spain. Start with the right cheek, then the left. If you're uncomfortable, a warm handshake is also acceptable, but the kisses show you're embracing their culture.
</CultureTip>

## Key Phrases for the First Meeting

<VocabCard
  word="He o√≠do hablar mucho de ustedes"
  translation="I've heard a lot about you"
  pronunciation="e o-EE-do a-BLAR MOO-cho de oos-TE-des"
  example="He o√≠do hablar mucho de ustedes. ¬°Todo bueno!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Gracias por invitarme"
  translation="Thank you for inviting me"
  pronunciation="GRA-thias por in-bi-TAR-me"
  example="Say this when arriving at their home."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Les he tra√≠do algo"
  translation="I brought you something"
  pronunciation="les e tra-EE-do AL-go"
  example="Les he tra√≠do un detalle."
/>

## Gift-Giving Etiquette

Bringing a gift is appreciated but not obligatory in Spain. Here's what works:

### Appropriate Gifts

| Spanish | English | Notes |
|---------|---------|-------|
| **Vino** | Wine | A quality bottle, especially from their region |
| **Dulces** | Sweets | Pastries or chocolates |
| **Flores** | Flowers | Nice bouquet (avoid dahlias - associated with funerals) |
| **Algo de mi pa√≠s** | Something from my country | Local specialties are valued |

<CultureTip title="Wine as a Gift" flag="üá™üá∏">
Spain is a wine country! Bringing wine is always appreciated, but be aware they might not open it immediately - they may save it for later. Don't be offended if they serve something else. If you know their region, try to bring wine from elsewhere to show variety!
</CultureTip>

## At the Dinner Table

Spanish meals are long, social affairs. Dinner typically starts late (9-10 PM) and can last hours.

<VocabCard
  word="¬°Qu√© buena pinta tiene esto!"
  translation="This looks delicious!"
  pronunciation="ke BWE-na PEEN-ta TYE-ne ES-to"
  example="Say this when food is served."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="¬°Est√° riqu√≠simo!"
  translation="It's absolutely delicious!"
  pronunciation="es-TA ree-KEE-see-mo"
  example="¬°Est√° riqu√≠simo! ¬øCu√°l es la receta?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="¬øPuedo repetir?"
  translation="May I have seconds?"
  pronunciation="PWE-do re-pe-TEER"
  example="Asking for more is a great compliment!"
/>

<CultureTip title="The Late Dinner" flag="üá™üá∏">
Spanish dinners are LATE by most standards. Don't be surprised if dinner starts at 9 or 10 PM! Eat a snack beforehand if needed. Also, expect sobremesa - the post-meal conversation that can last an hour or more. Don't rush to leave!
</CultureTip>

### Table Manners

| Do This | Why |
|---------|-----|
| **Keep hands on the table** | Spanish custom (not in lap) |
| **Engage in conversation** | Meals are social events |
| **Stay for sobremesa** | Post-meal chat is essential |
| **Try everything** | Shows appreciation |

## Family Vocabulary

| Spanish | Pronunciation | English |
|---------|---------------|---------|
| **la madre / mam√°** | la MA-dre / ma-MA | Mother / Mom |
| **el padre / pap√°** | el PA-dre / pa-PA | Father / Dad |
| **la abuela** | la a-BWE-la | Grandmother |
| **el abuelo** | el a-BWE-lo | Grandfather |
| **el hermano** | el er-MA-no | Brother |
| **la hermana** | la er-MA-na | Sister |
| **la t√≠a** | la TEE-a | Aunt |
| **el t√≠o** | el TEE-o | Uncle |
| **la suegra** | la SWE-gra | Mother-in-law |
| **el suegro** | el SWE-gro | Father-in-law |

## Polite Responses

| Spanish | English | When to Use |
|---------|---------|-------------|
| **S√≠, por favor** | Yes, please | Accepting offers |
| **Con mucho gusto** | With pleasure | Enthusiastic agreement |
| **Gracias, pero...** | Thank you, but... | Polite decline |
| **Encantado/a** | Delighted | For invitations |

## Handling Wine and Toasts

Wine is central to Spanish meals. Here's how to participate:

<VocabCard
  word="¬°Salud!"
  translation="Cheers! (To health!)"
  pronunciation="sa-LOOD"
  example="The standard toast. Make eye contact!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="¬°Por la familia!"
  translation="To the family!"
  pronunciation="por la fa-MEE-lya"
  example="A lovely toast when meeting the family."
/>

<CultureTip title="Never Empty Your Own Glass" flag="üá™üá∏">
In Spain, it's polite to fill others' glasses before your own. If your glass is empty, wait for someone to offer - or simply gesture toward the bottle. Also, never toast with water - it's considered bad luck!
</CultureTip>

## Saying Goodbye

<VocabCard
  word="Muchas gracias por todo"
  translation="Thank you so much for everything"
  pronunciation="MOO-chas GRA-thias por TO-do"
  example="Muchas gracias por todo. Ha sido una velada maravillosa."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Espero que nos veamos pronto"

  pronunciation="es-PE-ro ke nos BE-a-mos PRON-to"
  example="Express your desire for future meetings."
/>

<VocabCard

  translation="A pleasure to have met you"
  pronunciation="oon pla-THER a-BER-les ko-no-THEE-do"
  example="A warm, formal goodbye."
/>

## Things to Avoid

### Don't:
1. **Rush the meal** - Spanish dinners take hours
2. **Leave right after eating** - Stay for sobremesa
3. **Criticize food** - Even jokingly
4. **Discuss controversial topics** - Politics, Catalonia, etc. on first meeting
5. **Be too reserved** - Warmth is valued

### Do:
1. **Be warm and expressive** - Spanish culture is effusive
2. **Ask about family** - They love talking about relatives
3. **Compliment the food** - Multiple times!
4. **Try speaking Spanish** - They'll adore your effort
5. **Show interest in their region** - Spain is regionally proud

<CultureTip title="Regional Pride" flag="üá™üá∏">
Spain has strong regional identities. If your partner's family is from Catalonia, the Basque Country, Galicia, or Andalusia, show interest in their specific region. Ask about local traditions, food specialties, and maybe learn a phrase in their regional language if applicable!
</CultureTip>

## Sample Conversation

**You:** ¬°Hola! Encantado de conocerles.
**Parents:** ¬°Hola! Bienvenido/a. Pasa, pasa.
**You:** Les he tra√≠do vino.
**Mom:** ¬°Ay, qu√© detalle! Muchas gracias.
**You:** He o√≠do hablar mucho de ustedes.
**Dad:** Si√©ntate. ¬øQu√© quieres tomar?
**You:** Lo que ustedes tomen, por favor.

Good luck meeting the family! With warmth, good manners, and a few Spanish phrases, you'll make a wonderful impression.
